com.itko.lisaint

Class Integrator

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.itko.lisaint.Integrator
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    JavaIntegrator, ServletIntegrator

    public class Integrator
extends java.lang.Object
    This is the base class for all Lisa Integration methods. It has subclasses to handle iTKO's JPL, Servlets, custom Java code, EJBs, and others no doubt. The model used by Lisa Integration support is as follows:
    • A Lisa test case is defined with a certain Filter specified. This filter is built specifically for the kind of system under test. For example, the ServletFilter is used for a JSP/Servlet type application. This Filter knows how to "turn on" Lisa Integration support on the server side for those server applications that can be remotely turned on (EJB cannot, for example)
    • When the server is invoked, test-enabled server components use this class and other classes, primarily the TransInfo and possibly the CompInfo class to establish meaningful communication with the Lisa test case that is running. For example, if a Servlet fails in some way, it can call the TransInfo.setBuildStatus() to note the failure to Lisa.
    • Responses from the system under test are autoamtically processed by the Filter noted above. This Filter will log important information and process any commands from the tested component. How the server delivers the Integrator info back to Lisa is Server specific. Servlets use an object stream wrapped in an HTML comment block, for example.
    This class provides the base set of Integrator functionality.

      • fromXML

        public static Integrator fromXML(org.w3c.dom.Element iel)

      • startTransaction

        public TransInfo startTransaction(java.lang.String transID)
        This method is called by test-enabled components to notify the Lisa Integrator that a new transaction has started. A transaction can be a servlet, JSP page, EJB, or etc. If a transaction was aready running, then that transaction is forgotten completely and overwritten with this. This will start your info as a sub-scope to the currently running transaction.
        Parameters:
        transID - is any string that will best describe the transaction to the Lisa test case author so that she has an understanding of what the transaction is
        Returns:
        the transaction info object that was constructed around this new transaction

      • getCurTrans

        public TransInfo getCurTrans()
        This method will return the currently running transaction
        Returns:
        the current transaction, or will start one if there is not one defined

      • reset

        public void reset()
        For those server-side platforms that are not fully automatic (that's everyone but the JPL), you will need to call clearOldTrans() to make sure that a previous transaction is not accidentally used on a subsequent call. This is only an issue for persistent-session type severs, like the Servlet Integrator. Others may or may not keep the Integrator object. If not, then they construct a new Integrator for every call and have no need for this method. Note, the report() method will generally do this

      • getTransactionList

        public java.util.List<TransInfo> getTransactionList()
        Gives us all the transactions that have been loaded into this Integrator in the order that they were started.
        Returns:
        List of TransInfo objects

      • isLogTrace

        public boolean isLogTrace()
        For those Integrators that support sending all trace information to Lisa, this will tell you if the test case has requested that log data or not
        Returns:
        true if the test case has asked for trace information to be sent

      • setLogTrace

        public void setLogTrace(boolean logTrace)
        Called to turn on/off the request to log trace info from the server back to Lisa.
        Parameters:
        logTrace - true if we should report trace info to Lisa

      • isDebug

        public boolean isDebug()
        Some Integrators can request that a debug setting be turned on. This is generally left to the deveoper of the system under test to implement. It is automatic for the JPL. The definition of "debug" is not determined by Lisa. It can be made to mean whatever you wish.
        Returns:
        true if the test case author has asked for the server to run in a debug mode.

      • setDebug

        public void setDebug(boolean debug)
        Used to turn on/off the request to turn the sever debug mode on.
        Parameters:
        debug - true if you want the server to run in debug mode.

      • isLogCompContent

        public boolean isLogCompContent()
        Some servers support reporting their actual content on a component-by-component basis. Consider a Servlet chain in which each component class creates its own CompInfo object for example. The test case author can ask the server-side to report the content of each for text searches and etc.
        Returns:
        true if the test case author has asked for component content to be reported

      • setLogCompContent

        public void setLogCompContent(boolean logCompContent)
        Used to request logging of compnent content on or off
        Parameters:
        logCompContent - true if you want component content logging on

        This is a utility method used for parsing a string into a boolean value
        Parameters:
        val - the string to parse
        def - the default value if a valid boolean cannot be determined from val
        Returns:
        a boolean that is parsed from val, or the def value
